messages.message: Are you sure you would like to start a clean session?

Allows user to display reference photopeak lines from x-rays, gammas, or nuclear reactions.
Nuclides ages, applied shielding, and detector efficiency used can be edited.
In the extended info menu, you can also show cascade decay sums, alpha energies, or beta endpoints.
You can also export a CSV file with the nuclide information as well.
Displays information of fit peaks in a editable and sortable table, allows exporting a CSV of peak information, as well as utilities for automated search for peaks, and adding and deleting peaks.

Allows user to modify or fit energy calibration terms and non-linear deviation pairs.
There are also options to linearize the spectrum, change the energy calibration type, truncate the energy range, or combine channels.
Energy calibration can also be done graphically by right-click dragging the spectrum from original to modified energy (e.g., drag the data peak to the appropriate reference line).
Search for nuclides with constraints on energy, branching ratio, and half life.
Numeric, algebraic, and text-based spectrum interaction terminal.
Relative Efficiency analysis, from peaks you have fit.
Manage loaded spectra. Sum spectra, combine spectra into different files, display, ...
Saves the current app state to InterSpecs database
Saves the current app state to a new listing in InterSpecs database
Tags the current Interspec state so you can revert to at a later time. When loading an app state, you can choose either the most recent save, or select past tagged versions.
Starts a clean application state with no spectra loaded
Creates a dialog to browse for a spectrum file on your file system. Drag and drop the file directly into the app window as a quicker alternative.
Show measurement(s) location on a map. Only enabled when GPS coordinates are available.
Shows Time vs. Energy vs. Counts view for search mode or RPM data.
Shows the detectors ID analysis results included in the spectrum file.
Shows images included in the spectrum file.
Tool to show single/double escape peaks, Compton peak, Compton Edge, and sum peaks.

Tool to fit for the activity and shielding of nuclides in the spectrum.
Also contains capabilities to determine nuclide ages, contamination concentrations, or enrichments.

UNDER DEVELOPMENT.
Automatically fits nuclides peaks to allow determining the relative activities of nuclides. Does not require knowing the detector response or shielding information.
Uses the peaks you have fit to determine the relative activities of nuclides. Does not require knowing the detector response or shielding information.

Allows user to determine the cross section for gammas of arbitrary energy though any material in InterSpec's library. Efficiency estimates for detection of the gamma rays inside the full energy peak and the fraction of gamma rays that will make it through the material without interacting with it can be provided with the input of additional information.
Allows you to compute dose, activity, shielding, or distance, given the other pieces of information.
Allows user to use two dose measurements taken at different distances from a source to determine the absolute distance to the source from the nearer measurement.
Converts detected peak counts to gammas emitted by the source.
Allows user to obtain advanced information about activities, gamma/alpha/beta production rates, decay chain, and descendant nuclides.
Provides an upper activity estimate for nuclides
Allows user to change the detector response function.
Create detector response function from characterization data.

Allows user to view/edit the file parameters. If ever the application is unable to render activity calculation, use this tool to provide parameters the original file did not provide; InterSpec needs all parameters for activity calculation.
Sums the number of gammas in region of interest (ROI). Can also be accessed by left-click dragging over the ROI while holding both the ALT and SHIFT keys.
Searches through a directory (recursively) for spectrum files that match specified conditions.
Creates a terminal that provides numeric and algebraic computations, as well as allowing some text based interactions with the spectra.
Uses a{1} remote URL to perform nuclide identification on your spectrum.

Automatically stores application state if you are working in a stored state, or else if you are not, it will store your spectra and your work (e.g., peaks fit, energy cal changes, etc) into InterSpecs internal database and prompt you if you want to resume where you left off next time you load the same spectrum.
When a spectrum file is loaded, check if work (peak fits, activity fits, etc) has previously done on the same file.
Show tooltips after hovering over an element for half a second.
When loading spectra from the same detector, ask if should re-fit the same peaks for the new spectrum. Only applies if new spectrum doesnt have any peaks, but previous foreground did.
Display activity in units of becquerel, rather than curie.

When a spectrum is loaded, and you have not previously associated a detector response function with the model of detector the spectrum is from, whether a default DRF should try to be found and loaded automatically.

Selects to use either a more mobile or desktop style application interface. The primary difference is use of a "Hamburger" style menu, or a menu bar.
Changing this preference wont take effect until the app is restarted, or the "Clear Session..." option is chosen.
Applies the "Dark" color theme automatically according to the operating systems current value, or when it transitions.
At application start, ask to load previous state.
At application start, automatically load previous state, if not set to be prompted.
Changes will not take effect until app is restarted or refreshed.
Fixes the peaks FWHM to what the detector response function predicts, and then refits the peak.
Fixes the peak centroid to the assigned gamma energy, or if no source has been assigned, to likely reference photopeak line. After setting the centroid, the other peak parameters will be refit
I'm sorry there was a technical error saving your user state to the database.
There was no ROI to add peak to.
Sorry, cant add peaks to a ROI with a data defined peak.
Adding a peak did not improve overall ROI fit - not adding one.
There was no peak to delete.
You must load a foreground spectrum before viewing a background or second foreground spectrum.
The selected language, {1}, somehow isn't available.

This will save the current app state to the database - to export
as a separate file, use the "Export File" menu option

message.div:
The normal background subtraction option only affects display of the data, with operations like peak-fitting or exporting data are done on the full-statistics original foreground spectrum.
A "hard background subtraction" creates a modified foreground by doing a bin-by-bin subtraction of the background from the foreground.
Side effects of doing a hard background subtraction include:
Variances, i.e. the statistical uncertainty of each channel, will no longer be correct.
Small energy calibration differences between spectra may create artificial features in the data.
If a peak in the foreground overlaps with a peak in the background, the statistical uncertainty of fit foreground peaks will no longer be correct
The primary reasons to choose a hard background subtraction over normal display background subtraction are:
Avoiding artifacts on fit peak continuums.
To simplify background peak subtraction in the Activity/Shielding Fit tool.
You dont care about subtleties this causes (which in practice are minimal).

messages.message: Round channel counts to nearest integer
Using the detector response function you specified to use as default for this detector.
Have loaded a default detector response function for this detection system.
Warning, no energy calibration for the selected samples

This file looks like it's from the same detector as the current foreground.
How would you like to open this spectrum file?

message.p: The spectrum file didn't contain any spectra with the current sample numbers.
The spectrum file didn't contain any spectra with the current sample numbers and detector names.
Please select more detectors or sample numbers.
The current sample numbers and detector names only contain neutron data.
Please select samples that include spectroscopic data.
The current sample numbers and detector names do not include any spectroscopic measurements.
Please select samples that include spectroscopic data.
I couldn't determine binning to display the spectrum.
I couldn't determine binning to display the spectrum.
You might try selecting only a single spectra to display in the File manager, or a sample with gamma counts.
